thread.title: MIT engineers send innovative payloads to the Moon to support future lunar missions
thread.title_full: MIT engineers send innovative payloads to the Moon to support future lunar missions

author: Khiana Watson
title: MIT engineers send innovative payloads to the Moon to support future lunar missions
text:
MIT engineers send innovative payloads to the Moon to support future lunar missions
Three MIT-designed payloads will soon land on the moon’s south pole, gathering data to aid future Artemis astronauts and lunar settlement planning.
- More information:
NASA to drill into the Moon for water for future space missions
MIT engineers are launching three payloads to the moon’s south pole, marking a key step toward a sustainable lunar base. These payloads include a 3D imaging camera, a mini-rover, and a unique message from humanity. Their data will help NASA prepare for the Artemis III mission, which aims to land astronauts on the moon in 2027.
Mapping the Moon: How MIT’s 3D Camera Will Reveal the Lunar Surface
MIT’s cutting-edge 3D depth-mapping camera will be mounted on a Lunar Outpost rover, which will explore the moon’s surface. This camera will use time-of-flight technology to capture the first-ever detailed 3D images of the lunar terrain, even in permanently shadowed regions.
These images will be transmitted back to Earth, helping scientists study the moon’s frozen landscape. The data will also assist in training Artemis astronauts by incorporating realistic visuals into advanced spacesuits and simulations.
Meet AstroAnt: The Tiny Rover That Could Revolutionize Lunar Exploration
A tiny, thumb-sized rover named AstroAnt will travel with the main rover, playing a crucial role in monitoring the lunar environment. Using its magnetic wheels, AstroAnt will maneuver across the rover’s surface, collecting temperature data to assess the vehicle’s performance in extreme conditions.
If successful, AstroAnt could pave the way for a network of mini-robots working together on future missions.
These robotic assistants may one day perform vital tasks, such as dust removal from solar panels and structural inspections for lunar habitats.
A Message from Earth: MIT’s HUMANS Project Carries Voices to the Moon
The third payload, known as the HUMANS project, is a silicon wafer etched with messages from people worldwide. Inspired by NASA’s Golden Record, it carries voices and stories that celebrate humanity’s connection to space exploration.
Led by MIT AeroAstro alumna Maya Nasr (’18, SM ’21, PhD ’23), a disc, made from a silicon wafer, contains engraved messages from people worldwide, representing a diverse range of voices and cultures. This payload serves as both a time capsule and a testament to the universal spirit of curiosity and exploration.
This artistic and scientific project symbolizes the global nature of space discovery. As MIT continues its mission to “To the Moon to Stay,” the HUMANS project serves as a powerful reminder that space belongs to all of humanity.
News reference:
Chu, J. “MIT engineers prepare to send three payloads to the moon” https://news.mit.edu/2025/mit-engineers-prepare-send-three-payloads-moon-0225
